content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: funny, simple and clear problem. the difficulty is debatable.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: No comment.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great dynamic programming exercise! For some reason, dynamic programming does not come naturally to me.  Once I solved this problem, I was a bit shocked how long it took me to solve it. Maybe I need more practice just like this puzzle.  Nice work!

Two tiny formatting requests:

Please capitalize "Longest" in your title.

In the last line of the Goal, please change "got" to "get" and add a period at the end. (As for got/get, I believe the verb tenses should match between "you remove" and "you get".)

I like your puzzle, but I think the test cases are a bit too easy. I quickly put together a little recursive, brute force algorithm and easily passed all the test cases and validators. Pretty impressive, right? Actually, no. Your solution is 2000 (yes, two thousand) times faster than mine on Test 6.  

I don't really want to study your code since I should be learning what to do on my own, but I see you have a "dp" variable and I'm guessing you're doing some dynamic programming. If that is true, here's what I'd like to see:

1) If you are doing dynamic programming, add it to the tags to give us newbies a push in the right direction.

2) Consider making the test cases harder so a guy like me has to learn something cool rather than still getting a passing grade with a shockingly slow algorithm.

Please correct the following in Output section:
* "reprenste" => "represents"
* "lenght" => "length"
* "Increasing Subsequence" => "increasing subsequence"

Also, I think you may delete "or all" in Goal section?

Thanks.

Hi,

How do you select the sub-sequence to output?
Test1 you have 2 sub-sequences of 4 numbers 2-3-6-9 & 2-3-6-7
Test2 you have 4 sub-sequences of 3 numbers 9-10-13, 1-10-13, 5-10-13 & 6-10-13
...

All your tests & validators are identical, you need to make them different.

Input section
* Please format N as a [[variable]].

Output section
* Please mention "space-separated".

Cases
* Each pair of test and validator should be similar but remain different. Please revise the cases.
* I wonder if the case of N = 1 should be included? There are no "increasing" elements to speak of when there is only 1 number. (If the pair of cases of N = 1 is removed, then the constraint should be amended accordingly, i.e. change 1 to 2).

Thanks.

For N  = 1, I think you are right it is better to remove it.
I'll change it to  2 <= N <= 100 and remove the test case.

I don't understand that :
 Cases
* Each pair of test and validator should be similar but remain different. Please revise the cases.

Like for the test case 3
5
2
13
3
15
11

I change the validator :
5
3
12
8
9
11

I correct it to Find the length of the longest increasing subsequence in the list.

Cause it is more simple to explain 
And tests & validators are change !
I have added the dynamic programming tag, and put a test case with 2568 numbers maybe that should be good :p
Thank you. My terrible little algorithm cannot pass your new test cases. I will rework my solution and get back to you.

I finished the puzzle. I'm a bit embarrassed how long it took me to do it properly, but that is probably what makes this a medium puzzle.

Your entire puzzle is worded nicely and reads well.  I just have one thing I'd like to suggest.  I'd like the names of your test cases to present as nicely as the rest of your puzzle.  I don't care what the validators are named, but the test case names are part of the presentation.  You have 5 test cases that will be presented to the Codingamer.  I'd like you to change the names of those 5 test cases to something like:

Simple
Still Simple
Medium
Getting Harder
Lots of Numbers!

Other than that, I'm ready to approve.
The constraint on N should be updated. Thanks.
My bad. I should have caught that when I suggested making the test cases harder. I have updated the constraint for the author.
Yes, that may work. In this puzzle, I think similarity can be thought of in terms of complexity (e.g. due to the size of the list, or number of iterations required to find the solution).
